Flux Calibration Example Using HST image¶

From an HST image contained in our field of view, we compute the calibration bias of our SITELLE data cube. We integrate our sitelle data in the HST filter bandpass. The obtained ‘flux map’ is compared pixel by pixel to the HST flux map to compute the flux bias

In [1]:

#Should be removed in a regular python script
%matplotlib inline
from astropy import wcs
from orcs.process import SpectralCube
import numpy as np
from astropy.io import fits
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.interpolate import RectBivariateSpline
from orcs.core import Filter
from orb.utils.image import nanbin_image

We load the SITELLE data and adjust the WCS calibration (done beforehand)

In [2]:

SN2 = SpectralCube('../../fits/orig/M31_SN2.merged.cm1.1.0.hdf5')
SN2.set_wcs('../../fits/M31_SN2.1.0.ORCS/M31_SN2.1.0.wcs.deep_frame.fits')
SN2.set_dxdymaps('../../fits/M31_SN2.1.0.ORCS/M31_SN2.1.0.wcs.dxmap.fits', '../../fits/M31_SN2.1.0.ORCS/M31_SN2.1.0.wcs.dymap.fits')

We load our HST data. We are interested in the extension n°1 of the fits file

In [3]:

hst_file_path = '../../fits/HLA/hst_11714_96_wfc3_uvis_f502n/hst_11714_96_wfc3_uvis_f502n_drz.fits'
ext_num = 1

In [4]:

hst_data = fits.getdata(hst_file_path, ext_num).T #Transpose to match ORCS convention on indexing [x,y]
hst_header = fits.getheader(hst_file_path, ext_num)
hst_data = hst_data*hst_header['PHOTFLAM'] # We want our data to be in erg/cm2/A/s
hst_wcs = wcs.WCS(hst_header) #We need the WCS to make the two data set correspond

Instanciation of a Filter¶

We need to get the filter corresponding to our HST image

In [5]:

hst_filter_path = '../../fits/HST/HST_WFC3_UVIS1.F502N.dat.txt'

In [6]:

a = []
T = []
with open(hst_filter_path, 'r') as f:
    for line in f:
        tmp = map(float,line.strip().split(' ')) # We convert the line elemtnts into floats
        a.append(tmp[0]/10.) # to have nm
        T.append(tmp[1])
filter_axis = np.array(a) #the list are converted to numpy array for convenience
filter_transmission = np.array(T)
hst_filter = Filter(filter_axis, filter_transmission) # a Filter object is istanciated

Integration of SITELLE data in HST filter bandpass¶

For speed concerns, we don’t need to perform this integration over the whole SITELLE field of view, as HST images are usually much smaller. From image study, we determined here that our HST images was contained in SITELLE cube between pixels xmin, xmax = (980, 1170), ymin, ymax = (940, 1130)

In [7]:

#Hard coded large boundaries, to avoid computing integration the full cube
#Outside this region, the flux is set to NaN
xmin, xmax = 980, 1170
ymin, ymax = 940, 1130
sitelle_flux_map = SN2.integrate(hst_filter, xmin,xmax,ymin,ymax)
sitelle_flux_map[sitelle_flux_map == 0.] = np.nan

In [8]:

f,ax = plt.subplots()
im = ax.imshow(sitelle_flux_map.T, origin='bottom-left', cmap='jet')
ax.set_xlim(xmin, xmax)
ax.set_ylim(ymin,ymax)
f.colorbar(im)

Out[8]:

<matplotlib.colorbar.Colorbar at 0x7faf404c2c90>

Reprojection of HST data in SITELLE coordinates¶

HST pixel scale is about 10 times smaller that SITELLE’s. Therefore, we are going to interpolate HST values on an ovsersampled grid taken from SN2

In [9]:

scale_factor = 10.
X,Y = np.mgrid[xmin:xmax:1/scale_factor,ymin:ymax:1/scale_factor] #We intentionnally ovserwample our image
XYp = hst_wcs.all_world2pix(SN2.pix2world(np.array([X.flatten(),Y.flatten()]).T), 0)
Xp, Yp = XYp.T

Xp, Yp are now the coordinates of an oversampled SITELLE grid in HST image coordinates.

We perform a linear interpolation of HST image on this grid

In [10]:

projection_function = RectBivariateSpline(np.arange(hst_data.shape[0]),
                                          np.arange(hst_data.shape[1]),
                                          hst_data, kx=1, ky=1, s=0)

reprojected_HST = projection_function.ev(Xp.reshape(*X.shape),Yp.reshape(*Y.shape))

reprojected_HST is now HST image evaluated on the oversampled SITELLE grid.

We now bin this to SITELLE’s resolution. As nanbin_image computes the binned mean, we have to multiply by the number of pixels binned.

In [11]:

hst_flux_map = np.full_like(sitelle_flux_map, np.nan)
hst_flux_map[xmin:xmax, ymin:ymax] = nanbin_image(reprojected_HST, int(scale_factor))*(scale_factor**2)
hst_flux_map[hst_flux_map == 0.] = np.nan

We plot the resulting map

In [12]:

f,ax = plt.subplots()
im = ax.imshow(hst_flux_map.T, origin='bottom-left', cmap='jet')
ax.set_xlim(xmin, xmax)
ax.set_ylim(ymin,ymax)
f.colorbar(im)

Out[12]:

<matplotlib.colorbar.Colorbar at 0x7faf30c12490>

Flux Calibration¶

From this two maps, we can get the flux ratio (i.e. bias) between our datacube and HST data

In [13]:

ratio = hst_flux_map/sitelle_flux_map
f,ax = plt.subplots()
im = ax.imshow(ratio.T, origin='bottom-left', cmap='jet',
               vmax = np.nanpercentile(ratio, 99),
               vmin=np.nanpercentile(ratio,1))
ax.set_xlim(xmin, xmax)
ax.set_ylim(ymin,ymax)
f.colorbar(im)

Out[13]:

<matplotlib.colorbar.Colorbar at 0x7faf2cae2bd0>

This can also be plotted as an histogram

In [14]:

histo_data = ratio[~np.isnan(ratio)]
f,ax = plt.subplots()
ax.hist(histo_data, bins=300) # we need to remove the NaNs
_ = ax.set_title('Median = %.3f, Std = %.3f'%(np.median(histo_data), histo_data.std()))

The End¶

From now on, it’s up to the user to choose what to do with this : use it as is or try to clean this map/histogram from obvious outliers (edge effects, center of the frame).

What follows may thus be applicable only to this specific data, and be conceptually arguable

Cleaning¶

There is edge effects we want to correct

In [15]:

# First this little artefact
f,ax = plt.subplots()
im = ax.imshow(ratio.T, origin='bottom-left', cmap='jet',
               vmax = np.nanpercentile(ratio, 99),
               vmin=np.nanpercentile(ratio,1))
ax.set_xlim(979, 995)
ax.set_ylim(1048,1054)
f.colorbar(im)

Out[15]:

<matplotlib.colorbar.Colorbar at 0x7faf2c61a690>

In [16]:

ratio[980:991, 1050:1053] = np.nan

With visual check, we estimate that there is a ~2 pixels wide boundary of outliers around our ratio map, that we correct here.

In [17]:

for y in range(ymin, ymax):
    if y in range(1050,1053):
        continue
    line = ratio[:,y]
    if np.all(np.isnan(line)):
        continue
    nonnan_indices = np.nonzero(~np.isnan(line))[0].squeeze()
    try:
        imin, imax = nonnan_indices[0], nonnan_indices[-1]
        ratio[imin:imin+2,y] = np.nan
        ratio[imax-1:imax+1, y] = np.nan
    except IndexError:
        if nonnan_indices.shape == ():
            ratio[xmin:xmax, ymin+nonnan_indices] = np.nan

Conclusion¶

It is now a lot better

Optional¶

Gaussian smoothing¶

For our purpose, it can make sense to smooth the maps before dividing them to get a smoother output

In [20]:

from astropy.convolution import convolve, Gaussian2DKernel
kernel = Gaussian2DKernel(2)

smooth_hst_map = convolve(hst_flux_map, kernel)
smooth_sitelle_map = convolve(sitelle_flux_map, kernel)

In [21]:

smooth_ratio = smooth_hst_map/smooth_sitelle_map

WARNING| /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ipykernel_launcher.py:1: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in divide
  """Entry point for launching an IPython kernel.


In [22]:

f,ax = plt.subplots()
im = ax.imshow(smooth_ratio.T, origin='bottom-left', cmap='jet',
               vmax = np.nanpercentile(smooth_ratio, 99),
               vmin=np.nanpercentile(smooth_ratio,1))
ax.set_xlim(xmin-10, xmax+10)
